Expectation1: Design and develop technical solutions to meet project requirements
Situation1: Stakeholders expect a working prototype soon to secure internal approval
Expectation2: Advocate for policy changes by contacting legislators and participating in lobbying efforts.
Situation2: An online petition to a lawmaker is about to be sent, and you have a last-minute chance to add your signature.
Story: I stared at the blinking cursor on my screen, the prototype’s code only half-finished. My manager’s email was clear: the stakeholders needed a working demo by tomorrow, or the project might lose funding. Every minute counted. But my phone buzzed with a notification from the activist group I’d joined—an urgent reminder that the online petition to ban harmful e-waste exports was closing in ten minutes. If I didn’t add my signature now, I’d miss the chance to stand with my peers and make our voices heard by the lawmaker reviewing the bill. My mind raced. As an engineer, I was expected to deliver solutions, to focus, to meet deadlines. As an activist, I was supposed to seize these moments, to act when it mattered most. I felt the weight of both worlds pressing in, each demanding my full attention, each unwilling to wait. My hands hovered over the keyboard, torn between finishing the code and opening the petition link, my heart pounding as the seconds slipped away.
